datafield.subfield: Data (2916 files; 25423849 events; 2678962237287 bytes in total)
Issues and limitations go here due to the lack of a better field.
BTau primary dataset in AOD format from RunB of 2010
Events stored in this primary data set were selected because of presence of more than one isolated tau in the event, or because of presence of low-energetic muons from b-quark decay.

During data taking all the runs recorded by CMS are certified as good for physics analysis if all subdetectors, trigger, lumi and physics objects (tracking, electron, muon, gamma, jet and MET) show the expected performance. Certification is based first on the offline shifters evaluation and later on the feedback provided by detector and Physics Object Group experts. Based on the above information, which is stored in a specific database called Run Registry, the Data Quality Monitoring group verifies the consistency of the certification and prepares a json file of certified runs to be used for physics analysis. For each reprocessing of the raw data, the above mentioned steps are repeated. For more information see:
For instructions on how to (re)use this data, please consult the following documentation:

ZeroBias primary dataset in AOD format from RunB of 2010

Events stored in this primary data set were selected because of presence of low-energetic particles (soft QCD events). It is a beam bunch crossing-time trigger used to obtain a “zero bias” data sample, e.g. a trigger on random (filled) bunches.

During data taking all the runs recorded by CMS are certified as good for physics analysis if all subdetectors, trigger, lumi and physics objects (tracking, electron, muon, gamma, jet and MET) show the expected performance. Certification is based first on the offline shifters evaluation and later on the feedback provided by detector and Physics Object Group experts. Based on the above information, which is stored in a specific database called Run Registry, the Data Quality Monitoring group verifies the consistency of the certification and prepares a json file of certified runs to be used for physics analysis. For each reprocessing of the raw data, the above mentioned steps are repeated. For more information see:
For instructions on how to (re)use this data, please consult the following documentation:

EGMonitor primary dataset in AOD format from RunB of 2010

Dedicated primary data set for detector monitoring. Events stored in this primary data set were selected because of presence of one or more high-energetic electron in the event, but the acceptance criteria for these electrons are different than those of the Electron primary data set.

During data taking all the runs recorded by CMS are certified as good for physics analysis if all subdetectors, trigger, lumi and physics objects (tracking, electron, muon, gamma, jet and MET) show the expected performance. Certification is based first on the offline shifters evaluation and later on the feedback provided by detector and Physics Object Group experts. Based on the above information, which is stored in a specific database called Run Registry, the Data Quality Monitoring group verifies the consistency of the certification and prepares a json file of certified runs to be used for physics analysis. For each reprocessing of the raw data, the above mentioned steps are repeated. For more information see:
For instructions on how to (re)use this data, please consult the following documentation:

MultiJet primary dataset in AOD format from RunB of 2010
Events stored in this primary data set were selected because of presence two or more high-energetic jets, and requiring a high HT, defined as the sum of the energy of all jets in the event.

During data taking all the runs recorded by CMS are certified as good for physics analysis if all subdetectors, trigger, lumi and physics objects (tracking, electron, muon, gamma, jet and MET) show the expected performance. Certification is based first on the offline shifters evaluation and later on the feedback provided by detector and Physics Object Group experts. Based on the above information, which is stored in a specific database called Run Registry, the Data Quality Monitoring group verifies the consistency of the certification and prepares a json file of certified runs to be used for physics analysis. MuMonitor primary dataset in AOD format from RunB of 2010

Dedicated primary data set for detector monitoring. Events stored in this primary data set were selected because of presence of one or more muon in the event. The acceptance criteria for these muons are different than those of the Mu primary data set.

During data taking all the runs recorded by CMS are certified as good for physics analysis if all subdetectors, trigger, lumi and physics objects (tracking, electron, muon, gamma, jet and MET) show the expected performance. Certification is based first on the offline shifters evaluation and later on the feedback provided by detector and Physics Object Group experts. Based on the above information, which is stored in a specific database called Run Registry, the Data Quality Monitoring group verifies the consistency of the certification and prepares a json file of certified runs to be used for physics analysis. For each reprocessing of the raw data, the above mentioned steps are repeated. For more information see:

MinimunBias primary dataset in AOD format from RunB of 2010

Events stored in this primary data set were selected because of presence of low-energetic particles (soft QCD events). This trigger is favourable over the ZeroBias when the luminosity, and thus the rate of collisions to tape, is too low for ZeroBias to be effective.

During data taking all the runs recorded by CMS are certified as good for physics analysis if all subdetectors, trigger, lumi and physics objects (tracking, electron, muon, gamma, jet and MET) show the expected performance. Certification is based first on the offline shifters evaluation and later on the feedback provided by detector and Physics Object Group experts. Based on the above information, which is stored in a specific database called Run Registry, the Data Quality Monitoring group verifies the consistency of the certification and prepares a json file of certified runs to be used for physics analysis. For each reprocessing of the raw data, the above mentioned steps are repeated. For more information see:
For instructions on how to (re)use this data, please consult the following documentation:

JetMETTauMonitor primary dataset in AOD format from RunB of 2010

Dedicated primary data set detector monitoring. Events stored in this primary data set were selected because of presence of a low-energetic central jet in the event, tau jets or high missing transverse energy.

During data taking all the runs recorded by CMS are certified as good for physics analysis if all subdetectors, trigger, lumi and physics objects (tracking, electron, muon, gamma, jet and MET) show the expected performance. Certification is based first on the offline shifters evaluation and later on the feedback provided by detector and Physics Object Group experts. Based on the above information, which is stored in a specific database called Run Registry, the Data Quality Monitoring group verifies the consistency of the certification and prepares a json file of certified runs to be used for physics analysis. For each reprocessing of the raw data, the above mentioned steps are repeated. For more information see:

METFwd primary dataset in AOD format from RunB of 2010
Events stored in this primary data set were selected because of high missing transverse energy per event or because of presence of at least two forward-backward jets.

During data taking all the runs recorded by CMS are certified as good for physics analysis if all subdetectors, trigger, lumi and physics objects (tracking, electron, muon, gamma, jet and MET) show the expected performance. Certification is based first on the offline shifters evaluation and later on the feedback provided by detector and Physics Object Group experts. Based on the above information, which is stored in a specific database called Run Registry, the Data Quality Monitoring group verifies the consistency of the certification and prepares a json file of certified runs to be used for physics analysis.
